finding: The SNP rs1412444 in the LIPA locus was noted for its association with increased expression of LIPA and a counterintuitive relation with myocardial infarction (MI) risk, where homozygous minors had lower expression levels of LIPA under MI conditions.
title: Interpreting coronary artery disease GWAS results: A functional genomics approach assessing biological significance

finding: The SNP rs1051338 associated with LIPA expression was implicated alongside rs1412444, indicating that multiple functional variants may influence LIPA gene expression.
title: Interpreting coronary artery disease GWAS results: A functional genomics approach assessing biological significance

finding: Similarly, SNP rs2250781 was linked with LIPA gene expression. Like rs1051338, it demonstrated significant eQTL effects, indicating additional regulatory variants within the locus.
title: Interpreting coronary artery disease GWAS results: A functional genomics approach assessing biological significance

finding: The SNP rs11101586 was associated with the regulation of proliferation and differentiation of adipocyte progenitor cells (APCs). The study highlighted that mutations in the phosphatase and tensin homolog (PTEN), influenced by this SNP, were linked to PTEN Hamartoma Tumor Syndrome (PHTS) and related adipose tissue growth in patients. Specifically, PTEN knockdown resulted in enhanced APC proliferation and differentiation, with implications for aberrant adipose tissue growth.
title: PTEN regulates adipocyte progenitor growth, differentiation and cellular aging

finding: The study found that the enhancer variant rs2435357, known as RET+3, had strong enhancer activity when tested in the neuronal cell line Neuro2a. This finding served as a positive control for evaluating the effects of other identified <italic>de novo</italic> mutations associated with autism. The context implied that rs2435357 was relevant for understanding enhancer function within neurodevelopmental disorders, particularly in terms of its comparative analysis to the <italic>de novo</italic> mutations.
title: De Novo Mutation in an Enhancer of EBF3 in simplex autism

finding: The SNP rs11192233 was associated with migratory behavior in bird species, reflecting adaptations that facilitate seasonal migration. In the context of the broader research, this finding suggested a genetic basis for flight dynamics and migration patterns which were integral to understanding the ecological impact of migratory bird flows across regions, specifically in relation to the quantification of bird movements and their effect on ecosystems.
title: Quantifying year-round nocturnal bird migration with a fluid dynamics model

finding: Similar trends were observed with rs10761648, with its OR being significantly different between the combined UC cohort and the severe UC cohort, showcasing the heterogeneity of genetic risk.
title: An extremes of phenotype approach confirms significant genetic heterogeneity in patients with ulcerative colitis

finding: The CASP7 variant rs10553596 was associated with reduced risk of AD in APOE E4 homozygotes, marking it as a significant finding from a haplotype association study in Caribbean Hispanics.
title: How understudied populations have contributed to our understanding of Alzheimer’s disease genetics

finding: The rs10748818 variant was identified in relation to the NFKB2 gene, with significant association at a low minor allele frequency (MAF < 1%) contributing to PD risk.
title: Expanding Parkinson’s disease genetics: novel risk loci, genomic context, causal insights and heritable risk

finding: This SNP was noted to show significant departure from HWE after Bonferroni correction, suggesting population structure or other factors affecting its distribution.
title: Genomic history and forensic characteristics of Sherpa highlanders on the Tibetan Plateau inferred from high-resolution genome-wide InDels and SNPs

finding: For rs10761785, it was observed that both discovery and replication samples showed consistent pleiotropic association patterns, with a 95% confidence interval (CI) of the consistency measure being [0.46,1]. This strong consistency indicated that the pleiotropic effect was robust across different populations.
title: Beyond power: Multivariate discovery, replication, and interpretation of pleiotropic loci using summary association statistics

finding: The genetic variant rs117119468 (C-T) was identified as a strong candidate causal variant that completely abolished enhancer function within the IL2RA locus, impacting Jurkat T cells and HL60 cells in laboratory assays.
title: The Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA) Susceptibility Locus, IL2RA, Includes An Intronic Enhancer That Is Attenuated By JIA-Associated Genetic Variants

finding: The genetic variant rs12722502 (C-T) was found to reduce enhancer function by 30% in Jurkat T cells, but it had no effect on enhancer activity in HL60 cells, highlighting its role as a JIA-associated variant.
title: The Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA) Susceptibility Locus, IL2RA, Includes An Intronic Enhancer That Is Attenuated By JIA-Associated Genetic Variants

finding: The SNP rs7903146 at TCF7L2 was demonstrated to influence enhancer activities and was classified as a positive and original finding for T2D. Its role has been confirmed in previous work such as Gaulton et al., 2010.
title: Deep learning models predict regulatory variants in pancreatic islets and refine type 2 diabetes association signals

finding: The rs80194531 variant, resulting in an Asn78Thr substitution in the ZEB1 gene and reported as pathogenic for corneal dystrophy, was estimated to be 5,866 generations old, translating to an age of about 120,000 to 180,000 years. Despite its pathogenic classification, its frequency in African ancestry samples at only 6% raises questions about its unusualness among similarly prevalent variants.
title: Dating genomic variants and shared ancestry in population-scale sequencing data

finding: The SNP rs61839660 was associated with hay fever/eczema but also showed different effects in comparison with asthma, indicating its dual role in phenotype specificity.
title: Genome-wide association analysis of 350,000 Caucasians from the UK Biobank identifies novel loci for asthma, hay fever and eczema

finding: The SNP rs12722547 was linked to asthma and demonstrated a trend towards a larger effect in asthma-only compared to hay fever/eczema-only groups.
title: Genome-wide association analysis of 350,000 Caucasians from the UK Biobank identifies novel loci for asthma, hay fever and eczema

finding: It was found that the common SNP rs2435357, located in intron 1 of RET, affected SOX10 binding to a RET enhancer. This SNP explained 10-20 times the phenotypic variance compared to rare damaging RET variants and contributed to Hirschsprung disease (HSCR) pathogenesis by reducing RET expression in early enteric neural progenitors.
title: Whole-genome analysis of noncoding genetic variations identifies multigranular regulatory element perturbations associated with Hirschsprung disease

finding: The IBD risk allele linked to this SNP was shown to enhance the expression of MAP3K8 and modulate acetylation levels at the chromatin, crucial for Treg functionality.
title: Immune disease variants modulate gene expression in regulatory CD4+ T cells and inform drug targets

finding: Colocalized with an IBD-associated locus affecting MAP3K8, suggesting a significant role for this SNP in the regulatory network influencing Treg biology and IBD pathogenesis.
title: Immune disease variants modulate gene expression in regulatory CD4+ T cells and inform drug targets

finding: The study reported that rs7911488 was associated with the expression of miR-1307-5p, which is located within the 5' UTR of ATP5MK. Specifically, the G allele of rs7911488 was associated with an increased utilization of splice sites SpliceA and SpliceD, while it was concurrently associated with a decreased expression of miR-1307-5p. This indication of a complex relationship highlights how common genetic variation can influence both miRNA expression and splicing in its host gene.
title: MicroRNA-eQTLs in the developing human neocortex link miR-4707-3p expression to brain size

finding: The synonymous variant rs3824734 in CPEB3 was associated with cognitive functioning and was identified as an eQTL regulating its gene expression, thus potentially impacting cognitive processes.
title: Exome-wide analysis reveals role of LRP1 and additional novel loci in cognition

finding: The SNP rs5030938, showing the highest AdaptMix score of 3.79×10^-15, was linked to HKDC1 expression in liver and adipose tissues. It was inferred to indicate selection in Native Americans within the Peruvian cohort.
title: Disentangling signatures of selection before and after European colonization in Latin Americans

finding: The SNP rs11192209 was linked to the quantitative phenotyping of northern leaf blight using UAV images and deep learning techniques. This study underscored the role of genetic factors in disease resilience and indicated that deep learning approaches could enhance the accuracy of phenotypic assessments for this specific plant disease.
title: Global Genotype by Environment Prediction Competition Reveals That Diverse Modeling Strategies Can Deliver Satisfactory Maize Yield Estimates

finding: The intergenic SNP rs61863020 was associated with a lower prevalence of insomnia at baseline (OR 0.63 [0.52, 0.75], P-value = 4.74E-8). It was also identified as an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for ADRA2A in the brain, linking it to arousal and sleep regulation.
title: Genome-wide association study of Parkinson’s disease progression biomarkers in 12 longitudinal patients’ cohorts

finding: The rs12769205 variant was part of the haplotype necessary to annotate the CYP2C19 star allele *2 for sample NA19122, which matched the GeT-RM NGS consensus finding.
title: Star allele search: a pharmacogenetic annotation database and user-friendly search tool of publicly available 1000 Genomes Project biospecimens

finding: The rs4244285 variant was included in the haplotype needed to annotate the CYP2C19 star allele *2 for sample NA19122, corroborating the GeT-RM NGS findings.
title: Star allele search: a pharmacogenetic annotation database and user-friendly search tool of publicly available 1000 Genomes Project biospecimens

finding: The rs3758581 variant was also essential for the haplotype that annotated the CYP2C19 star allele *2 for sample NA19122, consistent with the GeT-RM NGS consensus.
title: Star allele search: a pharmacogenetic annotation database and user-friendly search tool of publicly available 1000 Genomes Project biospecimens

finding: The rs1799853 variant was found to correspond to the CYP2C9 star allele annotations for samples NA19143 and NA19213, which annotated as *1|*1 despite discrepancies with the GeT-RM NGS consensus.
title: Star allele search: a pharmacogenetic annotation database and user-friendly search tool of publicly available 1000 Genomes Project biospecimens

finding: The rs202201137 variant was essential for annotation of the CYP2C9 star allele *61 found in sample HG01190, which exhibited differences from the GeT-RM NGS consensus.
title: Star allele search: a pharmacogenetic annotation database and user-friendly search tool of publicly available 1000 Genomes Project biospecimens

finding: The finding related to SNP rs7903146 involved its hypomethylated enhancer and promoter binding sites for transcription factor 7-like 2 (TCF7L2), which was associated with type 2 diabetes (T2D) risk. This was part of a broader investigation into epigenetic biomarkers linked to MeHg exposure and the associated risks.
title: Epigenetic biomarkers of autoimmune risk and protective antioxidant signaling in methylmercury-exposed adults

finding: The SNP rs11101497 was associated with variations in metabolic pathways relevant to hepatocellular carcinoma. Previous studies indicated that modifications in lipid metabolism due to this SNP influenced the liver's response to anthracyclin treatment, particularly in relation to polyunsaturated fatty acids and their role in ferroptotic cell death.
title: Anthracyclins increase free PUFAs and etherPEs with PUFAs as potential hallmarks of lipid peroxidation and ferroptosis

finding: The SNP rs3740053, located in the promoter region of SIRT1, was linked to myocardial infarction (MI). Specifically, the -92A>G allele was identified as a MI-risk variant that hindered the oxidative stress-induced regulation of SIRT1. Experimental data showed that HEK293 cells carrying the -92G allele demonstrated significantly reduced induction of SIRT1 mRNA and protein levels upon Hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) treatment compared to those with the -92A allele, suggesting an impaired stress response mechanism. Functional assays indicated that the wild-type promoter linked to rs3740053 was activated upon H2O2 exposure, whereas the MI-risk variant failed to activate, further supporting the proposition that this SNP plays a critical role in transcriptional modulation of SIRT1 in the context of stress.
title: Recruitment of CTCF to the SIRT1 promoter after Oxidative Stress mediates Cardioprotective Transcription

finding: This SNP is associated with the ADK gene, previously linked to cognitive impairment and seizures, highlighting the genetic complexity related to Alzheimer’s disease.
title: Deep Learning-based Feature Extraction with MRI Data in Neuroimaging Genetics for Alzheimer’s Disease

finding: Similar to rs7719885, variant rs747334 was predicted to decrease NKX2-5 binding affinity, but the experimental validation showed an increase in binding affinity. This finding highlighted the variant's role in altering the DNA-binding properties of NKX2-5.
title: Disease-Associated Non-Coding Variants Alter NKX2-5 DNA-Binding Affinity

finding: The SNP rs7903146 was previously identified for its effects on islet chromatin accessibility, and through MPRA, it confirmed its transcriptional activating properties in beta cells.
title: Functional characterization of thousands of type 2 diabetes-associated and chromatin-modulating variants under steady state and endoplasmic reticulum stress

finding: The variant rs12254441 was identified as a significant association with body mass index (BMI) located in the intron of KAT6B. However, it was demonstrated to be an expression quantitative trait locus (eQTL) for the gene VDAC2 in subcutaneous adipose tissue. The study highlighted that this variant may serve as a functional link between VDAC2 and BMI, rather than KAT6B.
title: A Transcriptomic and Proteomic Atlas of Obesity and Type 2 Diabetes in Cynomolgus Monkeys

finding: The SNP rs7903146 was associated with metabolite changes related to purine catabolism and identified as having modifying effects in the context of type 2 diabetes incidence. This finding indicated a significant variant that contributed to the understanding of genetic susceptibility to type 2 diabetes, specifically linking to the TCF7L2 gene.
title: Functional Characterization of the Lin28/let-7 Circuit during Forelimb Regeneration in Ambystoma mexicanum and its Influence on Metabolic Reprogramming

finding: The association of rs1047991, a missense mutation in MTPAP, with methylation at position 13710 within mt-ND5 was replicated across multiple tissues, implying a broader role for MTPAP in mitochondrial RNA modification regulation.
title: Nuclear genetic regulation of human mitochondrial RNA modification

finding: In a large-scale AlzGene meta-analysis involving 1282 AD patients and 1312 controls from five independent populations, a significant association was found between the 'T' allele of rs13500 located in the promoter region of CH25H and the increased risk of developing Alzheimer's disease (AD), as well as differing rates of Aβ/amyloid deposition. Although this rs13500 association was not confirmed in two subsequent studies, a Turkish cohort study reaffirmed its strong association with AD and indicated an even greater risk factor presence in individuals carrying the APOE4 allele. This suggests the potential involvement of the CH25H gene in the pathogenesis of AD, particularly in relation to neuroinflammation and Aβ deposition.
title: 25-Hydroxycholesterol amplifies microglial IL-1β production in an apoE isoform-dependent manner

finding: The SNP rs17745507, tagged to the gene ADAM12, was associated with activity levels of the transcription factor GATA4 in cardiomyocytes. This finding suggested a novel relationship between GATA4 and cardiac hypertrophy, potentially mediated by ADAM12, linking genetic variants to cardiac development and function.
title: Monopogen: single nucleotide variant calling from single cell sequencing

finding: The SNP rs11010101 was associated with poor prognosis in breast cancer. This was indicated by its functional role in the expression of RhoU small GTPase and a subset of non-canonical WNT responsive genes, which were studied by Monteleone et al. in 2019. Their research highlighted how gene interactions and expression influenced survival-related networks within breast cancer, emphasizing this SNP's relevance as a potential target for therapy in aggressive breast cancer subtypes.
title: Network analysis allows to unravel breast cancer molecular features and to identify novel targets

finding: Despite being a coding variant, the rs1051338 SNP did not affect lysosomal trafficking or enzymatic activity of LIPA according to studies, which established that risk allele (C) of this SNP was associated with increased LIPA expression and enzyme activity in human monocytes, supporting its correlation with CAD risk.
title: Decoding the variant-to-function relationship for LIPA, a risk locus for coronary artery disease

finding: It was found that the SNP rs2246833, in high linkage disequilibrium with rs1412444 (r2 = 0.98), showed association with increased LIPA mRNA levels and activity, indicating it plays a significant role in CAD through enhancing expression of the LIPA gene.
title: Decoding the variant-to-function relationship for LIPA, a risk locus for coronary artery disease

finding: Variant rs34872471, with a PPA=0.36, mapped to a strong enhancer active only in adipose tissue while being in near perfect LD with rs7903146.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs2461864 was identified as a non-coding variant within a starvation-activated putative enhancer (Starv-Hi2-CRE) at the PLAU locus. This SNP was shown to be significantly associated with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) risk, with the T allele representing the risk-associated variant. It exhibited strong positive linkage disequilibrium with PLAU TSS-proximal SNP rs2227551, which had previously been identified as a Crohn's disease risk SNP. Additionally, the T allele of rs2461864 was strongly overrepresented in H3K27ac and H3K4me1 ChIP reads in cells heterozygous for this SNP, indicating its correlation with enhancer activity.
title: Nutrient starvation activates ECM remodeling gene enhancers associated with inflammatory bowel disease risk in fibroblasts

finding: The SNP rs2227551 was previously identified as a risk SNP for Crohn's disease, correlating with high PLAU expression in fibroblasts. This SNP exhibited strong linkage with the non-coding variant rs2461864, which was found within a starvation-activated enhancer at the PLAU locus, thereby implicating it in the transcriptional regulation of PLAU in the context of IBD.
title: Nutrient starvation activates ECM remodeling gene enhancers associated with inflammatory bowel disease risk in fibroblasts

finding: The SNP rs2227564 showed a positive association with increased risk of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), with a significant P-value for the association established in previous studies. This SNP was found to be in linkage disequilibrium with the risk-associated enhancer variant rs2461864, which is thought to play a role in the enhancer activity at the PLAU locus, consequently affecting PLAU expression.
title: Nutrient starvation activates ECM remodeling gene enhancers associated with inflammatory bowel disease risk in fibroblasts

finding: The SNP rs2688607 was associated with increased risk of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) with a significant P-value in related research. It was reported to be in linkage disequilibrium with the non-coding variant rs2461864, suggesting that alterations in this region may influence enhancer activity at the PLAU locus and PLAU gene expression.
title: Nutrient starvation activates ECM remodeling gene enhancers associated with inflammatory bowel disease risk in fibroblasts

finding: The SNP rs2688608 demonstrated a significant association with increased IBD risks. This SNP was also in positive linkage disequilibrium with rs2461864, underscoring its potential role in regulating enhancer activity at the PLAU locus and influencing PLAU gene expression in response to nutrient deprivation.
title: Nutrient starvation activates ECM remodeling gene enhancers associated with inflammatory bowel disease risk in fibroblasts

finding: The SNP rs11010099 was linked to the modulation of Wnt signaling pathways affecting cancer properties in breast cancer, referenced in research by Saha et al. in 2019. This regulation was significant in understanding the differential modulation of cancer signaling in this context.
title: Identification and Pharmacological Targeting of Treatment-Resistant, Stem-like Breast Cancer Cells for Combination Therapy

finding: The SNP rs11010103 was associated with increased mortality in carriers of the SDHB pathogenic variant, indicating a significant role in the clinical outcome of familial paraganglioma (PGL) linked to succinate dehydrogenase deficiency. This finding was derived from a study that analyzed the implications of such variants on patient survival, illustrating the importance of this genetic factor in the context of neuroendocrine tumors.
title: A chemical screen for suppressors of dioxygenase inhibition in a yeast model of familial paraganglioma

finding: Association studies revealed that rs150689919 in the DNA demethylation gene TET1 did not correlate with Parkinson's disease in the Chinese Han population, thus, questioning its impact.
title: Identification of key genes and signaling pathway in the pathogenesis of Huntington’s disease via bioinformatics and next generation sequencing data analysis

finding: RS10997355 was identified as an intron variant in the CTNNA3 gene, which is located on chromosome 10. This SNP was found in a study of major depressive disorder (MDD) and showed a significant association with the expression of SCAI, a gene involved in cancer cell invasion and cell cycle regulation. Additionally, a previous study indicated that this SNP might interact with maternal cytomegalovirus (CMV) status in the context of schizophrenia, highlighting its potential role in gene-environment interactions. Most notably, associations with CTNNA3 have also been observed in studies related to Alzheimer’s disease and autism spectrum disorder, suggesting its broader relevance in neuropsychiatric conditions.
title: Nearest-neighbor Projected-Distance Regression (NPDR) for detecting network interactions with adjustments for multiple tests and confounding

finding: The SNP rs11101618 was associated with cancer outcomes and was specifically related to the perturbations observed in cancer gene networks. The investigation revealed that over 56% of cancer treatment-related hub genes included this SNP, indicating its relevance in the prognosis across 32 types of cancers.
title: Network-based cancer gene relationship prediction method reveals perturbations in the cancer gene network

finding: The intergenic SNP rs1680636 was identified to interact exclusively with CXCL12 in a 200-kb loop and was associated with coronary artery disease (CAD) with an odds ratio (OR) of 1.111 (p=2.0E-16). Although influencing CXCL12 expression, it did not tag any eQTL within GTEx tissues.
title: Dissecting Regulatory Non-Coding Heart Disease GWAS Loci with High-Resolution 3D Chromatin Interactions Reveals Causal Genes with Pathophysiological Relevance to Heart Failure

finding: The SNP rs61839660 resided within the CaRE4 enhancer and was associated with a reduced risk (Odds Ratio = 0.62, p value = 2.8 x 10^-39) of developing Type 1 diabetes (T1D) while simultaneously increasing the risk of developing Crohn's Disease. This SNP's effect on IL-2ra expression was noted to mimic the effects seen with the Tconv-EDEL in activated Tconvs, albeit with a less pronounced impact when compared to enhancer deletion.
title: Non-coding sequence variation reveals fragility within interleukin 2 feedback circuitry and shapes autoimmune disease risk

finding: Located upstream of the PFKP gene, this SNP was identified among those greenlisted in relation to known L1 expression regulators, indicating its involvement in the regulation mechanisms.
title: Multi-ancestry GWAS reveals loci linked to human variation in LINE-1- and Alu-copy numbers

finding: The SNP rs11010106 was associated with the research by Shimaoka et al. (2019), revolving around connexins and integrins in exosomes. This relationship suggests that this SNP may impact signaling pathways that influence tumor behavior and metastatic potential in colorectal cancer.
title: Deciphering stiffness-driven changes in colorectal cancer by proteomics

finding: The SNP rs45596840 in miR-4482 showed significant RA association, suggested to influence more than 5,894 mRNA-miRNA bindings, impacting immune responses in RA patients.
title: MicroRNA variants and HLA-miRNA interactions are novel rheumatoid arthritis susceptibility factors

finding: At the TCF7L2 locus, the independent signal rs7918400 was assigned primarily to liver based on its TOA profile, implying differential regulatory mechanisms contributing to T2D.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The signal rs140242150 at TCF7L2 was also assigned to the liver, supporting evidence that one locus can exhibit multiple tissue-specific regulatory effects.
title: A multi-omic integrative scheme characterizes tissues of action at loci associated with type 2 diabetes

finding: The SNP rs112597538 was identified as a credible regulatory SNP that played a role in osteoporosis risk by overlapping a constitutive nucleosome-depleted region indicative of strong nucleosome phasing due to transcription factor binding, particularly impacting BMD risk.
title: Prioritization of osteoporosis-associated GWAS SNPs using epigenomics and transcriptomics

finding: The SNP rs1896245 was part of the Tier-1 SNPs connected to the gene BICC1, suggesting its involvement in canonical Wnt signaling linked to bone formation and repair in the context of osteoporosis.
title: Prioritization of osteoporosis-associated GWAS SNPs using epigenomics and transcriptomics

finding: The SNP rs1896243 was one of the Tier-1 SNPs in the region upstream of BICC1, contributing to inherited osteoporosis risk and was in moderate-to-high linkage disequilibrium (LD) with related SNPs.
title: Prioritization of osteoporosis-associated GWAS SNPs using epigenomics and transcriptomics

finding: The SNP rs1658429 overlapped enhancer chromatin and was part of the regulatory network for BICC1, supporting its association with bone mineral density and osteoporosis.
title: Prioritization of osteoporosis-associated GWAS SNPs using epigenomics and transcriptomics

finding: The SNP rs11006188 was identified among the BICC1 Tier-1 SNPs with evidence suggesting it influences eQTL data, indicating its potential regulatory role linked to osteoporosis.
title: Prioritization of osteoporosis-associated GWAS SNPs using epigenomics and transcriptomics

finding: The SNP rs1982173 contributed to inherited osteoporosis risk and was involved in transcriptional regulation mechanisms pertinent to BICC1.
title: Prioritization of osteoporosis-associated GWAS SNPs using epigenomics and transcriptomics

finding: The SNP rs4948523 was shown to have overlapping effects with promoter or enhancer chromatin, supporting its regulatory function for BICC1 in the context of osteoporosis.
title: Prioritization of osteoporosis-associated GWAS SNPs using epigenomics and transcriptomics

finding: Variant rs17158558 was linked with HIRSCHSPRUNG disease, featuring a VDA score of 0.7, suggesting that this association is supported by at least one curated source.
title: Comprehensive assessment of Indian variations in the druggable kinome landscape highlights distinct insights at the sequence, structure and pharmacogenomic stratum
